data.title: KNOW your AUDIENCE
questions: In this phase, surface all you know about the audience to position the presentation.
Who’s in the audience? What do you know about them?
Based on their preferences, how should you adapt your style?
What does the audience know and not know about your topic?
What do they care most about? What matters most to them?
What do you want them to know, feel and do when it’s over?
Who are likely opinion leaders? How open/receptive are they?
What’s your c#cc2229ibility with them? How can you enhance it?
Who can vouch for your knowledge/expertise? Recommend you?
What’s a strong opening or provocative question you could ask?
What quote, statistic or image could launch the presentation?

data.title: DEVELOP the PITCH
questions: In this phase, imagine how you might sell the idea to this group…
Tell a story about how they/their organization got ‘here’.
Frame their need, challenge or problem as a question: “What if…”
Position your idea as answering that question. Make it big.
Transport them to a future where the problem is solved.
Connect your idea/solution to something the audience cares about.
Give them a compelling vision of how they will feel, think and act.
Be sure to stress the risks and consequences of not acting urgently.
Compare/benchmark their actions (or lack of) to their competition.

data.title: KNOW your #s
questions: In this phase, collect and present all supporting data to make your case.
Describe in detail your proposal. “Here’s how we get there…”
Gear background information to an above-average audience.
Make a evidence-based case for your approach.
Cite specific, objective data supporting your idea, and acknowledge contrarian data/research.
Use persuasion techniques such as contrast, social proof, and commitment & consistency.

data.title: ANTICIPATE Qs
questions: In this phase, anticipate potential questions from as many perspectives as possible.
What are likely questions? How will you respond if asked…?
What off-the-wall questions might be asked? How will you handle them?
Where are the ‘holes’ in your proposal? What could go wrong?
End each answer with a reminder of your idea's potential to solve.

data.title: PROPOSE a PLAN
questions: In this phase, develop and present your plan to implement/achieve your idea…
Develop a plan for making it happen: actions, responsible person, timeline.
Establish a target start date and deadline for implementation.
Acknowledge any key challenges, assumptions or caveats in your plan.
Identify factors especially critical to success and resources needed.

data.title: CALL to ACTION
questions: In this phase, decide how you will get their full and willing commitment to your idea…
Call for a commitment from the audience: ask them to approve.
If their response is hesitant, ask them to take one concrete step forward.
Don’t leave without at least a small commitment in your direction.
Say 'THANK YOU’…and leave.
